none: Letter to Louis L. McInnis from C. P. Estill, July 15, 1881
Letter to Louis L. McInnis from C. P. Estill, July 15, 1881
Box 1 Louis L. McInnis Papers/Box 1 Folder 9 Louis L. McInnis Papers

body.value:
[Header]

State A. & M. College of Texas.

College Station, Brazos County,

July 15th 1881

My Dear Mr Lunis,
Your letter was
duly received, and for its
friendly sentiments I thank
you from the bottom of my
heart. My separation from the
College, I keenly feel - My as-
sociation with many of you
has been nothing but pleasant.
I am candid enough to say,
it has not been so with all -
and of course, the separation
from them causes no regret.
Was not the manner of my
"taking off" singular? The Board
left me here, so far as any of
them interviewed me, with the
belief that everything would work
out right, - so far as I was con-
cerned, and that nothing had
been determined upon. I would

**Analysis and Transcription of a Handwritten Letter**

Alright, let's break this down. My goal is to get a perfect transcription of this letter. First, I have a header: "State A. & M. College of Texas." in a formal gothic style. Then, "College Station, Brazos County," in a more flowing cursive. It's dated "July 15th 1881", with the '1' added by hand. The letter begins "My Dear Mr. Lunis," which, admittedly, the name is giving me a bit of trouble, but from what I can see, it looks like "Lunis," though "Lewis" is a possibility that I am tracking, and even the obscure "Innis" is feasible based on the handwriting.

The body of the letter is where the real work is. The text starts with a gracious acknowledgement of a letter received, expressing thanks for the "friendly sentiments". The writer then mentions a separation from the college, which is clearly a sensitive topic. It sounds like the writer is leaving or has left. The writer also reflects on the separation, and I must preserve the implied tone of candor and perhaps a bit of bitterness. Then there's an abrupt question about the nature of the writer's "taking off," with the phrase in quotes. This hints at some sort of controversy. The writer tells me that the board seemed to believe that everything was going to be alright, but clearly something has happened. Then, the letter just cuts off in the middle of a sentence, which is frustrating.

I'm transcribing carefully, line by line, preserving the original formatting as closely as possible, including line breaks and punctuation. I'm focusing on "Mr. Lunis", which seems to be the most accurate read of the name. If it turns out to be "Lewis" or even "Innis", I will need to make an addendum, noting the original ambiguity and the reasoning I followed. I will use appropriate HTML tags to reproduce the text exactly. I'm noting any variations in style or punctuation, like the raised "th" in the date. The exclamation/question mark is a point of concern as well. I'm prepared to provide all relevant notes. I have one task: Perfect accuracy.

State A. & M. College of Texas.

College Station, Brazos County,

not be, until they met at Hous-

while Harrison was at Navasota,

day night; & it appeared in the "News"
of Saturday. They met in Houston
Saturday, & in Sunday Morning's
Post the proceedings appear, &
the Records make it to have
been done there. What sort of
"hocus pocus", do you call that,
for honorable straight-forward
men? I call it trickery, of the
smallest kind. Their Resolutions
can do me no possible good.
But it has been in their power
to to me an incalculable dam-
age. In the peculiar circumstan-
ces existing here, the dropping

I see a piece of stationery from the State A. & M. College of Texas, with "College Station, Brazos County" and a pre-printed "188" date line. There are handwritten additions that appear to be archival notes ("(2) [1881, July 15]"). The main body is handwritten script, seemingly from the late 19th century. The ink is a bit faded, but legible. The content is about a meeting and accusations of "trickery" relating to records. Now, the transcription. Line by line, I'm carefully transcribing, noting any peculiarities or potential ambiguities. I see the archival notation, the printed letterhead, the sub-header, and the date line. The body text will be a bit more involved. I have a crucial moment to handle, the word "Prarie" – or is it "Pratie" or "Prairie"? It is likely a misspelling of "Prairie". I'll be really attentive to the handwriting of 'r' and 't' throughout, as it's common. I am also paying attention to the spelling of place names and making sure capitalization is correct. I am noting the repetition of the word "to" in line 19 ("to to me"), which I need to preserve, even though it appears redundant. Now for refining: I'll use the HTML tags to structure the output. I am very attentive to how the "Prarie"/"Pratie" appears. I'll stick with "Prarie" as the closest readable text that makes sense, as the context is clear. The key is faithfulness to the image. of one Professor (& but one has been

ter far, in that view of it, that I
had never come near the place.
I have always been aware
that under the new policy, my chair
was more endangered than any
other - not necessarily so however.
I believe that, if the Governor had
not come here, the step would
not have been taken - before
another year at least. There would
have been some propriety in the
step, when the University had been

**Alright, here's what I'm thinking:** I'm starting with this handwritten letter and the goal is to get a clean transcription. First, I need to understand the basic structure: there's a header with some handwritten annotations and a printed part, a date line, and then the body of the letter. I need to make sure I capture everything accurately, including any strange characters or potential ambiguities in the handwriting. I'm carefully examining the header. I see that there are two handwritten elements: "(3)" and "[1881, July 15]". It's pretty straightforward, probably some archival notations. Then there's the printed part, which is in a gothic font: "State A. & M. College of Texas." followed by "College Station, Brazos County," and the date line with just "188" pre-printed. Now, into the body. The handwriting is a loopy cursive, typical of the late 19th century. I'm going line by line, really looking at each word. The first line, "of one Professor..." is the start. I have to make sure I get the sentence structure correct. I need to make sure I transcribe the "&" properly (looks like a plus sign), and I'm watching for all the tiny quirks of the penmanship. I see something scribbled above "dropped", but it looks like the words, "is a stigma upon him" are added to the same sentence. I'm careful with punctuation – that dash and the end of each line can be tricky. The trickiest part is definitely the word in line 9, "had." It's written in a way that is just a little off. The penmanship is a bit messy, and it looks like "hald". But, after checking the context, and looking at the other letters. It looks like it is `had`. It must be an unusual flourish. I'm double-checking every word and noticing any capitalization issues (like "University" is capitalized). I'm also watching for any marks or periods at the ends of lines. The last line ends with "meas-", which is cut off but must be "measures". I'm creating a draft transcription, refining it with these details, and checking the text against the image, line by line. I have to create an output with all the information in the right place. I'll make sure to preserve all line breaks using `

(4) [1881, July 15]

State A. & M. College of Texas.

College Station, Brazos County,

ures than were adopted, faithfully supported by his Man Friday here – and with a new Board just appointed by him, perhaps nothing less was to be expected. I have heard that the Governor is mad that Gartner & Kellner did not go too, & charges it all upon Pfeuf- fer. This I was told in Austin, the other day, But you need not tell Gartner this – for it will only make him uncomfortable – and God knows, he has a path before him, not to be envied. James, you will observe, has every thing ab- solutely in his own hands in the matter of Optional Studies – And I think he will make the Supt, a complete "figure head", by the close of the session – Gartner, however, collected his loan, before he

**Initial Analysis and Transcription Process**

Okay, here's what I'm thinking as I approach this transcription: I have a clear role – transcriptionist. My task is to accurately reproduce the text from this image, which appears to be a handwritten document, likely a letter. I've got to maintain fidelity to the original spelling, punctuation (even if it's a bit odd), the overall layout, and interpret any handwriting quirks. I'll use HTML tags as specified. I'm focusing solely on providing the transcription; no analysis or commentary in the final output.

I can see from the image that it's a letter on what looks like official stationery, with a header in a distinctive gothic font: "State A. & M. College of Texas." Below that, there's a script font that says "College Station, Brazos County." There are archival notations in pencil, specifically "(4) [1881, July 15]" which are likely date/ID markings. The writing is cursive, and generally legible, but there are instances of cramped words and some ambiguity. The content seems to deal with some internal political maneuverings at the college, involving key figures like a "Governor," "Gartner," "Kellner," "Pfeuffer," and a "James."

Now, line by line: I'm carefully reading and interpreting each word. I'm already seeing some challenges with the handwriting. For example, the first word of the body seems to be cut-off, but with some close examination and context, I think it is "ures." I'm mentally making notes of potential uncertainties. I will render "to be" to "to be".

I'm making a note of any proper nouns like "Man Friday," as they are capitalized. I'm taking my time with ambiguous words, like the word, which turns out to be "Supt." Looking at the handwriting very closely, I'm analyzing the ink flow, letter shapes and surrounding words to give me the most accurate transcription.

I'm keeping an eye on the bigger picture of the text as I transcribe. Context is key! For example, when I saw "Pfeuffer," I recalled some of the history of A&M. This helps to confirm my understanding. Now, I will double check, given the people involved, if there is another valid word. "Dept" (Department) or "Supt" (Superintendent). I have to ensure the final output reflects my best interpretation of the visual information. I am comparing the "Supt" transcription against "Dept" or "Prest" to ensure it fits the historical context and the visible ink marks.

I've decided to transcribe "Supt". Given the historical context, the personalities mentioned, and the nature of the document. Also, I am taking into account the quotations marks around "figure head". I am making sure the output is faithful to the original, including capitalization, hyphenation, and the use of quotation marks. The "188" part is pre-printed so I won't transcribe it. Okay, I've got a final version. I have added the HTML tags and formatted the text according to the instructions. I have added the pencil note. I have added the pre-printed date/number. I am checking the crop. Done!

**Final Transcription and Analysis** Alright, let's get this done. The task is to transcribe this image of a handwritten letter, and I've got a handle on the nuances. The main challenge? This "dokument" in line 8. It's clearly intended to be "document", but the handwriting *really* makes it look like it starts with a "k", or perhaps a stray "l". Since I am not meant to autocorrect, but preserve the original, I am going with "dokument". Here's the breakdown of my transcription process: 1. **Image Analysis:** I started by visually dissecting the image. The header is important, so I had a good look at that gothic font and the script of "College Station". Also, the marginalia "(5) [1881, July 15]" is going to get included, since it is archival. 2. **Transcription Guidelines:** I'm sticking to the rules: top-to-bottom order, preserving everything – spelling, punctuation, capitalization – and using the specified HTML tags. No commentaries. 3. **Specific Challenges & Decision Making:** * **"left." vs. "loft":** The first word – it's definitely "l-f-t," but the vowel is a closed loop, so it can be 'e' (as in "left") or 'o' (as in "loft"). I am going with "left," as the more common one, and also grammatically, the sentence makes sense: "He has nothing left." * **"you Bachelor's":** The "you" is clear; "Bachelor's" is possessive plural. The "rut of you Bachelors" implies an opinion on a group of bachelors. The dash or period at the end of this sentence is also important for sentence construction. * **"dokument":** This is where it got tricky. The word is clearly *meant* to be "document", but that third letter is a tall loop that looks like a "k". I can confirm with the shapes of the other "c" characters that they are all small curves. I had an in-depth analysis looking at the 'k's and 'c's in the text to determine this was in fact, the closest possible interpretation of the glyph. However, it still looks like a "k". Given the instruction that I must preserve original spellings, I transcribed it as "dokument". I am unsure of the choice, but I must follow instructions. * **"Cooper's place":** The person mentioned is likely Oscar H. Cooper, a historical figure. The context of Texas education in 1881 is very relevant here, and the location of "Cooper's place" may refer to his role in Sam Houston State. 4. **Formatting and Structure:** The pencil notations are marginalia and should be preserved. The date line (the "188" part) needs to be addressed. I am retaining the dashes and the line breaks and other punctuation such as commas, periods, dashes, and question marks. Also the exclamation point in line 11! 5. **Final Checks:** I did a final content read-through and double-checked the "k" again, to make sure it was an acceptable transcription, given I cannot autocorrect. All other words are as seen. Now, here's my final, faithful transcription with markup: ```html

strong influence – Brown, Comptrol
ler, a member of the Board of Educa-
tion, and McLeary, Attorney General
are working for me. I had a long chat
with the Governor – nothing was said
about things down here – but a great
deal about the Normal School, & Smith
that I did not care about. I told him
I was a Candidate, but did not ask
his support, and do not know what
he will do – It all depends upon his vote
I have other "irons", but all in the
same undeveloped state. Am getting
very impatient. Wish I had the power
to turn over this house to you & Gart-
ner – Do not let those infernal Yankees
get it. I am anxious to get out, I do
assure you – and shall not lose a
moment, when I know where to go
But I have written too much. If Mrs
E knew I was writing, she would join me
in kind wishes – Truly your friend – [Signature] C. P. Estill
